content: Justice Department political appointees overruled career lawyers and ended a civil complaint accusing three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense of wielding a nightstick and intimidating voters at a Philadelphia polling place last Election Day, according to documents and interviews. The incident - which gained national attention when it was captured on videotape and distributed on YouTube - had prompted the government to sue the men, saying they violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act by scaring would-be voters with the weapon, racial slurs and military-style uniforms. Career lawyers pursued the case for months, including obtaining an affidavit from a prominent 1960s civil rights activist who witnessed the confrontation and described it as “the most blatant form of voter intimidation” that he had seen, even during the voting rights crisis in Mississippi a half-century ago. The case had already been won by the DOJ, by default.
reply: Justice Department political appointees overruled career lawyers and ended a civil complaint accusing three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense of wielding a nightstick and intimidating voters at a Philadelphia polling place last Election Day, according to documents and interviews. The incident - which gained national attention when it was captured on videotape and distributed on YouTube - had prompted the government to sue the men, saying they violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act by scaring would-be voters with the weapon, racial slurs and military-style uniforms. Career lawyers pursued the case for months, including obtaining an affidavit from a prominent 1960s civil rights activist who witnessed the confrontation and described it as “the most blatant form of voter intimidation” that he had seen, even during the voting rights crisis in Mississippi a half-century ago. The case had already been won by the DOJ, by default.
title: DOJ Drops Voter Intimidation Case

content: Yes, I do believe that the DOJ was wrong in dropping the "case". It had already been won by default, and dropping a case that has been won by default, to quote a DOJ staffer, is unheard of. When a case is won by default, it's becuase there was no response to the charges by the defendants. If there was no fault on the part of the defendants, why wasn't there a rush by liberal lawyers, like from the ACLU, to defend them? Probably because they didn't want to be associated in any way with this case. If you can watch the video and say that their intent was not to intimidate, both with their actions and comments, then it's because you agree with this type of behavior. A prominent 1960s voter and civil rights attorney, one that witnessed voter intimidation in 1960s Mississippi, said that he's never seen anything like that. I suppose that makes him a liar?

content: quote: Originally posted by psychoABN: Yes, I do believe that the DOJ was wrong in dropping the "case". A prominent 1960s voter and civil rights attorney, one that witnessed voter intimidation in 1960s Mississippi, said that he's never seen anything like that. I suppose that makes him a liar? I asked about charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers". What proof do you have that the organization is culpable? (None, I know...it was a rhetorical question). “Claims were dismissed against the other defendants based on a careful assessment of the facts and the law,” DOJ spokesman Alejandro Miyar said in a statement. “The Department is committed to the vigorous prosecution of those who intimidate, threaten or coerce anyone exercising his or her sacred right to vote." On Election Day, two men in uniforms stood outside the polling station with one of them holding a police-style baton weapon and saying he was providing security there. Justice has alleged that person was Shabazz. "http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/28/justice-department-drops-charges-in-voter-intimidation-case/" The rest is hyperbole... I do believe that the individual that was brandishing the club should have done some jail time or paid a hefty fine, but this won't be the last time I'm disappointed with our justice system. (I live in CA where the ridiculous "three strikes" is the law of the land)

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. They also dropped charges against two of the members. They got an injunction on the third that prevents him from ever brandishing a weapon outside a polling place. Sounds like the Justice Department doing their job. Where is the story exactly? Can you honestly say that had it been two jamokes sporting KKK logos that the case would have been dropped? Racism and intimidation should be stopped and prosecuted no matter who is engaging in it. It this case the DOJ has ill served the citizens of America. ACLU stayed out of it because what the thugs did--the particular thugs at that polling place--was indefensible. You'd likely have seen the ACLU rushing to defend a white conservative Republican who'd been intimidated, had they bothered to call the cops and report it. There are more immediate methods of redress available when a thug challenges a citizen's right to vote. Turn off the camera and call 911. Gather a few of the onlookers and chase them off--hate group logos and nightsticks in public point up some cowards who don't handle initimidation well themselves. Odd to hear the conservatives begging for Federal intervention when a beatdown and arrest by local authorities would have provided a much more salutary solution... The right thing was done, and the event was well documented. To do otherwise would be to invite hate crime charges, because it's obvious that hate crimes only work one way and aren't equally enforced. We have to trust that the government entities that are responsible for enforcing equal protection will do so.

content: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. They also dropped charges against two of the members. They got an injunction on the third that prevents him from ever brandishing a weapon outside a polling place. Sounds like the Justice Department doing their job. Where is the story exactly?

content: Yes, I do believe that the DOJ was wrong in dropping the "case". It had already been won by default, and dropping a case that has been won by default, to quote a DOJ staffer, is unheard of. When a case is won by default, it's becuase there was no response to the charges by the defendants. If there was no fault on the part of the defendants, why wasn't there a rush by liberal lawyers, like from the ACLU, to defend them? Probably because they didn't want to be associated in any way with this case. If you can watch the video and say that their intent was not to intimidate, both with their actions and comments, then it's because you agree with this type of behavior. A prominent 1960s voter and civil rights attorney, one that witnessed voter intimidation in 1960s Mississippi, said that he's never seen anything like that. I suppose that makes him a liar?

content: quote: Originally posted by psychoABN: Yes, I do believe that the DOJ was wrong in dropping the "case". It had already been won by default, and dropping a case that has been won by default, to quote a DOJ staffer, is unheard of. When a case is won by default, it's becuase there was no response to the charges by the defendants. If there was no fault on the part of the defendants, why wasn't there a rush by liberal lawyers, like from the ACLU, to defend them? Probably because they didn't want to be associated in any way with this case. If you can watch the video and say that their intent was not to intimidate, both with their actions and comments, then it's because you agree with this type of behavior. A prominent 1960s voter and civil rights attorney, one that witnessed voter intimidation in 1960s Mississippi, said that he's never seen anything like that. I suppose that makes him a liar? I asked about charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers". What proof do you have that the organization is culpable? (None, I know...it was a rhetorical question). “Claims were dismissed against the other defendants based on a careful assessment of the facts and the law,” DOJ spokesman Alejandro Miyar said in a statement. “The Department is committed to the vigorous prosecution of those who intimidate, threaten or coerce anyone exercising his or her sacred right to vote." On Election Day, two men in uniforms stood outside the polling station with one of them holding a police-style baton weapon and saying he was providing security there. Justice has alleged that person was Shabazz. "http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/28/justice-department-drops-charges-in-voter-intimidation-case/" The rest is hyperbole... I do believe that the individual that was brandishing the club should have done some jail time or paid a hefty fine, but this won't be the last time I'm disappointed with our justice system. (I live in CA where the ridiculous "three strikes" is the law of the land)

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. They also dropped charges against two of the members. They got an injunction on the third that prevents him from ever brandishing a weapon outside a polling place. Sounds like the Justice Department doing their job. Where is the story exactly? Can you honestly say that had it been two jamokes sporting KKK logos that the case would have been dropped? Racism and intimidation should be stopped and prosecuted no matter who is engaging in it. It this case the DOJ has ill served the citizens of America. ACLU stayed out of it because what the thugs did--the particular thugs at that polling place--was indefensible. You'd likely have seen the ACLU rushing to defend a white conservative Republican who'd been intimidated, had they bothered to call the cops and report it. There are more immediate methods of redress available when a thug challenges a citizen's right to vote. Turn off the camera and call 911. Gather a few of the onlookers and chase them off--hate group logos and nightsticks in public point up some cowards who don't handle initimidation well themselves. Odd to hear the conservatives begging for Federal intervention when a beatdown and arrest by local authorities would have provided a much more salutary solution... The right thing was done, and the event was well documented. To do otherwise would be to invite hate crime charges, because it's obvious that hate crimes only work one way and aren't equally enforced. We have to trust that the government entities that are responsible for enforcing equal protection will do so.

title: DOJ Drops Voter Intimidation Case

content: Justice Department political appointees overruled career lawyers and ended a civil complaint accusing three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense of wielding a nightstick and intimidating voters at a Philadelphia polling place last Election Day, according to documents and interviews. The incident - which gained national attention when it was captured on videotape and distributed on YouTube - had prompted the government to sue the men, saying they violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act by scaring would-be voters with the weapon, racial slurs and military-style uniforms. Career lawyers pursued the case for months, including obtaining an affidavit from a prominent 1960s civil rights activist who witnessed the confrontation and described it as “the most blatant form of voter intimidation” that he had seen, even during the voting rights crisis in Mississippi a half-century ago. The case had already been won by the DOJ, by default.
reply: Justice Department political appointees overruled career lawyers and ended a civil complaint accusing three members of the New Black Panther Party for Self-Defense of wielding a nightstick and intimidating voters at a Philadelphia polling place last Election Day, according to documents and interviews. The incident - which gained national attention when it was captured on videotape and distributed on YouTube - had prompted the government to sue the men, saying they violated the 1965 Voting Rights Act by scaring would-be voters with the weapon, racial slurs and military-style uniforms. Career lawyers pursued the case for months, including obtaining an affidavit from a prominent 1960s civil rights activist who witnessed the confrontation and described it as “the most blatant form of voter intimidation” that he had seen, even during the voting rights crisis in Mississippi a half-century ago. The case had already been won by the DOJ, by default.
title: DOJ Drops Voter Intimidation Case

A prominent 1960s voter and civil rights attorney, one that witnessed voter intimidation in 1960s Mississippi, said that he's never seen anything like that. I suppose that makes him a liar?
reply: I asked about charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers". What proof do you have that the organization is culpable? (None, I know...it was a rhetorical question). “Claims were dismissed against the other defendants based on a careful assessment of the facts and the law,” DOJ spokesman Alejandro Miyar said in a statement. “The Department is committed to the vigorous prosecution of those who intimidate, threaten or coerce anyone exercising his or her sacred right to vote." On Election Day, two men in uniforms stood outside the polling station with one of them holding a police-style baton weapon and saying he was providing security there. Justice has alleged that person was Shabazz. "http://politicalticker.blogs.cnn.com/2009/05/28/justice-department-drops-charges-in-voter-intimidation-case/" The rest is hyperbole... I do believe that the individual that was brandishing the club should have done some jail time or paid a hefty fine, but this won't be the last time I'm disappointed with our justice system. (I live in CA where the ridiculous "three strikes" is the law of the land)
title: DOJ Drops Voter Intimidation Case

content: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. They also dropped charges against two of the members. They got an injunction on the third that prevents him from ever brandishing a weapon outside a polling place. Sounds like the Justice Department doing their job. Where is the story exactly? Can you honestly say that had it been two jamokes sporting KKK logos that the case would have been dropped? Racism and intimidation should be stopped and prosecuted no matter who is engaging in it. It this case the DOJ has ill served the citizens of America.
quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. Against the KKK, yes...against the individuals, that is up to the lawyers. Personally, I think he should have been charged with a hate crime since he was, allegedly, shouting racial slurs.

title: DOJ Drops Voter Intimidation Case

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: quote: Originally posted by adminnco1: quote: Originally posted by SeaWitch1220: They dropped the charges against the organization, "The New Black Panthers" since culpability by the organization cannot be proven. They also dropped charges against two of the members. They got an injunction on the third that prevents him from ever brandishing a weapon outside a polling place. Sounds like the Justice Department doing their job. Where is the story exactly? Can you honestly say that had it been two jamokes sporting KKK logos that the case would have been dropped? Racism and intimidation should be stopped and prosecuted no matter who is engaging in it. It this case the DOJ has ill served the citizens of America. ACLU stayed out of it because what the thugs did--the particular thugs at that polling place--was indefensible. You'd likely have seen the ACLU rushing to defend a white conservative Republican who'd been intimidated, had they bothered to call the cops and report it. There are more immediate methods of redress available when a thug challenges a citizen's right to vote. Turn off the camera and call 911. Gather a few of the onlookers and chase them off--hate group logos and nightsticks in public point up some cowards who don't handle initimidation well themselves. Odd to hear the conservatives begging for Federal intervention when a beatdown and arrest by local authorities would have provided a much more salutary solution... The right thing was done, and the event was well documented. To do otherwise would be to invite hate crime charges, because it's obvious that hate crimes only work one way and aren't equally enforced. We have to trust that the government entities that are responsible for enforcing equal protection will do so.

ACLU stayed out of it because what the thugs did--the particular thugs at that polling place--was indefensible. You'd likely have seen the ACLU rushing to defend a white conservative Republican who'd been intimidated, had they bothered to call the cops and report it. There are more immediate methods of redress available when a thug challenges a citizen's right to vote. Turn off the camera and call 911. Gather a few of the onlookers and chase them off--hate group logos and nightsticks in public point up some cowards who don't handle initimidation well themselves. Odd to hear the conservatives begging for Federal intervention when a beatdown and arrest by local authorities would have provided a much more salutary solution...
reply: The right thing was done, and the event was well documented. To do otherwise would be to invite hate crime charges, because it's obvious that hate crimes only work one way and aren't equally enforced. We have to trust that the government entities that are responsible for enforcing equal protection will do so.
